comments.raw_text:
I can confirm the OP's findings.

But I do not know what the /intended/ result should be?

IMO, because one Profile was opened in Safe Mode, I would /not/ expect subsequent Profiles to be opened likewise, by default - via Switch Profile or other means.

If you were prompted, something like, "Existing Profile in -safe-mode, continue in Safe Mode or open normally?", I would have no problem with that.
 
 
(Odd perhaps how my feelings differ on Bug 658280 - Switch Profile does not Prompt to Save existing Session Restore ;-).)

comments.text:
So let me tell you a little story.

As I'm looking at bugs, I'm generally starting each session in -safe-mode.

I come across (your ;-) ) Bug 657275 - Need Better Visual Demarcation of Which Tab Has Focus.  And I'm switching themes (Apply Theme) & restarting, looking at differences.  And from time to time I notice that even though I have selected Modern, & Apply Theme seems to indicate I am in Modern, it sure looks like I am in Default.

After the fact, it dawns on me, that -safe-mode is disabling Modern theme.

And I also now see that a restart due to an Apply Theme change, restarts, applies the selected theme /& does NOT retain Safe Mode selection/.  (Can you see a new bug coming, or did you file it already ;-).)

So if what I describe is a bug, & should not happen, then why should this bug be different?  Perhaps it rightly so is a bug that needs to be fixed.

So then perhaps more generally, any action that causes a browser restart should retain its previous Mode, unless the restart was explicitly generated by the user, following a Quit (Ctrl+Q or Exit).

comments.raw_text:
Re comment #2.  I agree.  I am changing the Summary.  

While SeaMonkey is in Safe Mode, any restart not resulting from the user explicitly shutting down SeaMonkey should cause SeaMonkey to remain in Safe Mode.  Thus, restarts initiated by Profile Manager, Add-ons Manager, etc -- even from a user selecting a component option to restart -- should retain the mode of the instance that is being shut down.
